metadata.title: Boltzmann Meets Nash: Energy-Efficient Routing in Optical Networks under Uncertainty

sections.text: Motivated by the massive deployment of power-hungry data centers for IT service provisioning, we examine the problem of routing in optical networks with the aim of minimizing traffic-driven power consumption. To tackle this issue, routing must take into account energy efficiency as well as capacity considerations; moreover, in rapidly-varying network environments, this must be accomplished in a real-time, distributed manner that remains robust in the presence of random disturbances and noise. In view of this, we derive a pricing scheme whose Nash equilibria coincide with the network’s socially optimum states, and we propose a distributed learning method based on the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. Using tools from stochastic calculus, we show that the resulting Boltzmann routing scheme exhibits remarkable convergence properties under uncertainty: specifically, the long-term average of the network’s power consumption converges within ε of its minimum value in time which is at most Õ(1/ε2), irrespective of the fluctuations’ magnitude; additionally, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the algorithm converges to it – again, no matter the noise level. Our analysis is supplemented by extensive numerical simulations which show that Boltzmann routing can lead to a significant decrease in power consumption over basic, shortest-path routing schemes in realistic network conditions.

I. Introduction
In recent years, the Internet has become the cornerstone of global telecommunications, to the point that it now plays an integral part in sustaining the growth of the world economy. Specifically, as more and more users are using the Internet for backing up data, video on demand (VoD), device synchronization and other IT services, datahungry applications are experiencing a wildfire growth that affects almost all aspects of modern-day, always-connected societies. As a result, optical networks must grow fast enough so as to avoid experiencing a “capacity crunch” that will cripple their ability to handle the requested traffic in a reliable and efficient manner [3].

2 At the same time however, energy consumption in data networks must also be kept in check: in total, power consumption from information and communications technology (ICT) applications has been estimated to 4% of the global energy consumption [4], with a steeply rising trend as we progress toward the Internet of Things (IoT) era. In particular, just in the United States, Internet equipment consumes a staggering 8% of the total energy with a predicted growth of 50% within a decade [5]. Therefore, in addition to the always-present requirements of minimizing latencies and maximizing throughput, there is a key developing need to operate optical networks in an energy-aware way that minimizes power expenditure to the bare minimum. This last goal becomes especially prominent when taking into account the power needs of large switching and data centers (DCs) which are rapidly becoming a dominant term in the power consumption equation due the huge amounts of traffic that they service [6, 7].
In this paper, motivated by the massive deployment of power-hungry data centers described above, we examine the problem of routing traffic with the aim of minimizing the network’s traffic-driven power consumption. To achieve this, centralized optimization is not an option, because it is neither scalable nor flexible. Instead, one needs distributed load management as close as possible to the link level while ensuring that routing choices strike an optimal balance between “greener”, more efficient – but possibly congested – network facilities and “hungrier”, legacy resources that may be under-utilized. To tackle this issue, we derive a game-theoretic pricing scheme [8] which reconciles the selfish solution concept of (nonatomic) Nash equilibrium with social optimality (i.e. states that minimize global power consumption in the network). Building on this equivalence, we further propose a distributed learning scheme based on the Botlzmann distribution of statistical mechanics, which bears strong ties to replicator-based methods [9–12] and the class of exponential learning schemes used in finite (atomic) games [13–15].
Exploiting these links, we are able to show that the proposed routing scheme converges rapidly to a socially efficient state – in practice, within a few iterations. However, a key limiting factor in these considerations is that data traffic may exhibit significant spatiotemporal fluctuations because different applications have highly variable characteristic time scales. In addition, obtaining perfect information on the energy consumption of each switch/data center is a very challenging task in large networks due to real-time propagation delays, hierarchical topology aggregation and update sparsity (so as to keep the signaling overhead in check) [16–18]. This uncertainty is exacerbated further in highly dynamic networks where state information becomes obsolete very fast; accordingly, it is not clear whether a routing scheme designed for static, deterministic networks can maintain its convergence properties under uncertainty and noise.
To account for this crucial challenge, we focus on the performance of the proposed Boltzmann routing method in the presence of unpredictable stochastic disturbances. Using tools from stochastic analysis and Itô calculus [19, 20], we show that Boltzmann routing is exceptionally robust in this regard: first, by finetuning the choice of the method’s so-called inverse temperature, we show that the network’s long-term average consumption converges within ε of its minimum value in at most Õ(1/ε2) time, irrespective of the fluctuations’ magnitude. Moreover, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the method converges to it almost surely (a.s.), no matter the degree of volatility. Finally, if the network instead admits an interior, fully-mixing optimum state, the proposed scheme remains arbitrarily close to said state with probability arbitrarily close to 1, provided that the scheme’s inverse temperature parameter is
3 taken sufficiently small.
The performance of Boltzmann routing is validated by means of extensive numerical simulations modeling an optical data network deployed over the largest metropolitan centers of the continental US. Our results show that Boltzmann routing represents a scalable and flexible method that reduces traffic-driven energy consumption by a factor of 40% over simple shortest-path/closest-destination routing modes, even under high degrees of volatility and uncertainty.
Paper outline
In Section II, we present our network energy consumption model and a Pigouvian pricing scheme based on the theory of nonatomic congestion games. Subsequently, in Section III, we introduce the proposed Boltzmann routing method, first in a deterministic and then in a fully stochastic environment. Our main theoretical results (outlined above) are presented in Section IV, in both a deterministic and a stochastic context. Finally, Section V contains our numerical simulations in practical optical networks with diverse link, switching, and data center specifications. To streamline our presentation, technical proofs have been relegated to a series of appendices at the end.
II. SystemModel and Problem Formulation
In this section, we describe our model for power consumption in optical networks where traffic demands are routed towards a set of service provisioning infrastructures – the network’s data centers (DCs). After a few preliminaries in Section II-A, we discuss the specifics of power consumption in Section II-B and we present our game-theoretic model and pricing scheme in Section II-C.
A. Preliminaries
Following the standard traffic model of [21–25], we begin with a finite undirected graph with vertex set V and edge set E , describing respectively the network’s nodes and links. We assume that traffic in the network is generated in continuous streams by a set of source nodes S ⊆ V , each node s ∈ S generating traffic demands at rate %s > 0 towards a set of destination nodes Ds ⊆ V . In our setting, the traffic generated at each node represents the aggregation of the demands of a very large number of infinitesimal, nonatomic users – for instance, a city’s smartphone users accessing a cloud-based service. By the same token, the destination set Ds represents the network’s data centers (or a subset thereof), so each traffic element generated at source s is to be delivered in an anycast fashion to any one of the destination nodes in Ds (for a schematic representation, see Fig. 1).1

Proof: The first part of our claim is a classic result that follows immediately from the compactness of X and the convexity of each ce, e ∈ E – see e.g. [23, 26]. For our second assertion, simply note that if the network’s cost functions are strictly convex and increasing, C is strictly convex as a function of w, so it admits a unique solution w∗. Hence, if Π is invertible on X , the equation w∗ = Πx∗ admits a unique solution x∗ ∈ X , as claimed. The above result shows that the network’s set of socially optimum states has some fairly desirable attributes; however, it does not provide a way for the network’s users to compute (or otherwise converge to) such a state in a distributed way. This question underlies much of this paper’s motivation, so we address it in detail in Sections III and IV.
B. Energy consumption in optical data networks
As we mentioned in the introduction, traffic-driven power consumption in optical data networks occurs at two basic levels: (i) at the link level (including all wavelength-related and transmission line elements); and (ii) at the data center level (including all costs to service, process and/or store demands at the network’s data centers, cooling, etc.) [27, 28]. We will thus consider two types of power consumption functions:
1) Link-based consumption. At the transmission line, power consumption typically comprises two parts: a) a traffic-
independent component (due to amplification and other factors); and b) a traffic-dependent component, proportional to the number of active wavelengths per link (including the cost of switching, electrical-to-optical and optical-to-electrical conversion, etc.). Assuming that wavelength granularity is sufficiently fine, the number of wavelengths needed to carry a traffic load w is itself proportional to w, leading to the link-based model [28, 29]
clink(w) = Alink + Blink w, (4a)

C. Pigouvian pricing and Nash equilibrium
In a fully distributed environment, the system designer would like to ensure that the network’s nonatomic (infinitesimal) users make socially optimal routing choices while unilaterally minimizing the price they pay for accessing the network and utilizing its resources. Following Pigou’s theory of pricing [31], our approach to achieve this will be to charge agents for the externalities that they induce at a socially optimum state; in so doing, one can then ensure that such states constitute an equilibrium of the agents’ selfish interactions [8, 25].
To make this precise, suppose that a user that sends an infinitesimal amount of traffic dx through edge e ∈ E is charged πe(we) dx where πe(we) is the price per unit of traffic on edge e at load we. The total amount charged over path α ∈ A will then be πα(x) dx =
∑ e∈α πe(we) dx, (8)
so a (nonatomic) user will be satisfied with his routing choice if the charged price πα(x) is the lowest among all other available paths/destinations [32]. Formally:
Definition 1. A state x∗ ∈ X is at Nash equilibrium if, for all paths α ∈ A with x∗α > 0, we have
πα(x∗) = min β∼α πβ(x∗), (NE)
where the minimum is taken over all paths β ∼ α originating at the same source as α. In words, x∗ is a Nash equilibrium when every nonatomic user chooses the least expensive path.
We will also say that x∗ is an interior (or fully-mixing) Nash equilibrium if x∗ ∈ int(X ), i.e. if it employs all paths α ∈ A; by contrast, x∗ will be called strict (or non-mixing) if arg minα∈As πα(x∗) is a singleton for every source node s ∈ S.

As such, in the rest of this paper, we will assume that prices are set in accordance to Proposition 3, so that socially optimum states for (CM) coincide with the network’s Nash equilibria under π.
III. Boltzmann Routing
In this section, we present a distributed routing scheme to attain a socially efficient state based on a logit-type learning rule inspired from statistical mechanics. This scheme consists of two basic steps: First, each source node s ∈ S keeps a running “score” for each path starting at s by aggregating the associated end-to-end price over time. Then, every nonatomic user based at s chooses a path (and hence, a destination node d ∈ Ds) with probability inversely proportional to the exponential of this performance score – in analogy to the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics.
For generality, throughout this section, we focus on the global minimization problem (CM) with consumption functions satisfying Assumption 1; the specifics of energy efficiency in optical data networks are discussed in Section V. To streamline our presentation, we first develop our routing scheme in a deterministic setting with perfect information. Subsequently, we extend our model to a fully stochastic setting where the network is subject to random perturbations (arising e.g. from fluctuations in background traffic, link quality, estimation errors, etc.). We then present our convergence analysis and theoretical results in Section IV.
A. Boltzmann routing
The first step in setting up our routing scheme is to introduce a path’s “score”, interpreted here as a cumulative measure of the path’s price over time. More precisely, if x(t) denotes the state of the system at time t, we define the
9 score of path α ∈ A as yα(t) = yα(0) + ∫ t 0 πα(x(s)) ds, (11) i.e. as the cumulative price of path α over the time interval [0, t] (the value yα(0) is an arbitrary constant that represents an initial assessment of the path’s price).
Clearly, high scores indicate commensurately high prices, so such paths should be selected with low probability. We thus posit that a nonatomic user starting at s selects path α ∈ As with probability given by the Boltzmann distribution
Pα(t) ∝ exp(−η(t) yα(t)), (B)
where η(t) > 0 is an inverse temperature parameter whose role is explained below. Thus, writing (11) in differential form and invoking the law of large numbers to obtain the flow induced by (B), we obtain the Boltzmann routing scheme
ẏα = πα(x), xα = %s exp(−ηyα)∑ β∈As exp(−ηyβ) , (BR)
where s ≡ s(α) denotes the starting point of α and %s is the corresponding traffic generation rate. These routing dynamics will be at the core of our paper, so a few remarks are in order:
a) Basic properties: The Boltzmann scheme (BR) enjoys the following desirable properties: (P1) It is consistent: xα(t) ≥ 0 and ∑ α∈As xα(t) = %s for all t ≥ 0, so x(t) is a valid state variable. (P2) It is reinforcing: traffic elements tend to be routed along paths with lower prices. (P3) It is stateless: routing choices do not require knowledge of the network’s state. (P4) It is distributed: each node only needs to monitor the price of the paths that start at said node.
We should also note that (BR) has fairly low requirements in terms of computational complexity. Specifically, each node s ∈ S only needs to run a cheap update on |As| variables; since the set of paths being utilized by each source node is typically small (for instance, those with the minimum hop count), every node s ∈ S only needs to process at most O(Ds) ≤ O(V) variables. By comparison, the application of distributed flow-deviation methods [21] would require each node to keep track of O(E) link variables and then run at each step an O(V2) shortest path algorithm, leading to updates of significantly higher complexity.
b) Relation to the replicator dynamics: If we differentiate the network’s state variable x in (BR), a straightforward

In particular, for low η, the Boltzmann distribution (B) tends to select paths uniformly; by contrast, for high η, the induced choice probabilities “freeze” down to a hard best-response scheme which routes all traffic along the path with the lowest score. Thus, to counterbalance the O(t) growth of the variables yα(t), we will assume throughout that η(t) is nonincreasing with decay rate slower than 1/t:
Assumption 2. η(t) is C1-smooth, nonincreasing, and limt→∞ η(t)t = ∞.
In thermodynamic terms, Assumption 2 means that the system is being heated over time (instead of being cooled). This comes in stark contrast with simulated annealing and log-linear learning [36] where the system begins at a high sampling temperature (η ≈ 0) and subsequently freezes to very low temperatures (η → ∞) to approach a state of least energy. The reason for taking a heating schedule in (BR) is that the energy levels yα(t) of the system at hand are not fixed (as in simulated annealing) but, instead, they grow over time. As a result, if the paths’ prices (whose aggregation determines the system’s energy levels) are subject to randomness, freezing the system may lead it to quench prematurely to a suboptimal state; we explore this issue in detail in Section IV.
B. Routing under uncertainty
A key assumption underlying the (deterministic) Boltzmann routing scheme (BR) is that prices are assumed immune to exogenous stochastic fluctuations. IV. Convergence Analysis
Our aim in this section will be to analyze the long-term convergence properties of the proposed Boltzmann routing scheme in the presence of noise and uncertainty. To establish a baseline, we begin with the scheme’s convergence properties in a noiseless, deterministic setting:
Theorem 1. Under (BR), x(t) converges to a solution of the global minimization problem (CM).
Given the connection of (BR) to the replicator dynamics, Theorem 1 (proven in Appendix B) represents a strengthening of known convergence results for potential [44] and stable games [45]. Specifically, [44] showed that the replicator dynamics (RD) converge to the set of rest points in potential games; however, since the rest points of (RD) are not necessarily solutions of (CM), we cannot use the analysis of [24, 44] to deduce the convergence of (BR) to a globally efficient state. More recently, [12] established the convergence of (RD) to the game’s equilibrium set, but under the implicit assumption that the network’s routes are linearly independent (an assumption that fails automatically if |A| > |E | because Π fails to be invertible on X in this case). Instead, Theorem 1 dispenses with all such assumptions and provides an unconditional convergence result for (BR).
This behavior of (BR) is fairly encouraging, but it is contingent on the absence of fluctuations and uncertainty. If the network is constantly subject to stochastic disturbances, there is no reason to expect that this convergence still holds beyond the “small noise” regime. V. Numerical Results
In this section, we assess the performance of the proposed Boltzmann routing scheme in practical scenarios via numerical simulations. For clarity, we only present here a representative subset of these results but our conclusions apply to a wide range of optical network parameters and specifications.
Our setup is as follows (for an overview, see Table I): we consider an optical network deployed over the continental US with nodes and links as in Fig. 1 (for clarity, we only plotted the 50 largest metropolitan areas) [49]. At each link, data is transmitted over 80 wavelength-division multiplexing (WDM) channels spaced at 50 GHz, each with a carrying capacity of 10 Gb/s. To mitigate signal losses, each link carries an amplifier per 80 km of fiber length,

and an additional amplifier at each end; in addition to the amplifiers, power is also consumed at the transponder and switch port levels (cf. Table I) [28]. Source nodes are drawn randomly in the network, each with a traffic rate between 200 Gb/s and 400 Gb/s; this traffic is then directed to a set of data centers, also drawn randomly from the network’s nodes. Each data center has a capacity of 2 Tb/s and consumes between 6.6 kW and 13.2 kW, at zero and full load respectively [27]; for diversity, we also populate the network with a number of “legacy” data centers with lower capacity and higher power consumption specifications as indicated in [50].
In Fig. 2, we examine the performance of the proposed Boltzmann routing scheme in terms of power consumption, convergence speed and scalability. Specifically, we consider several different structures for the source nodes’ choice sets As: a) taking the shortest path to the closest destination (|As| = 1); b) splitting traffic over the 4 paths with the lowest hop count to the closest destination (|As| = 4); c) splitting traffic to the 5 closest destinations over shortest paths (|As| = 5); and d) mixing shortest paths and closest destinations (|As| = 4 × 5). We then run the Boltzmann routing scheme (BR) with the Pigouvian pricing scheme of Proposition 3 (πe = c′e), a heating schedule of the form η(t) ∼ t−1/2 and all scores initialized uniformly at Y(0) = 0 (of course, in the single-path, single-destination case, there is nothing to learn).
As shown in Fig. 2(a), Boltzmann routing converges very rapidly (within a few iterations) to a socially efficient network state that solves the corresponding consumption minimization problem (CM). Moreover, we see that splitting traffic over several data centers (as opposed to exclusively targeting the closest data center) leads to significant performance gains, of the order of 100 kW/(Gb/s) – approximately a 40% decrease in power consumption with respect to closest-destination routing. Finally, in Fig. 2(b), we examine the scalability of these performance gains as the number of source nodes increases: in so doing, we observe that a) the relative percentage gain of splitting traffic over multiple data centers becomes more prominent for large numbers of sources; and b) the Boltzmann routing scheme retains its convergence speed and attains a socially efficient state within 4–5 iterations, even for S = 100 source nodes. This means that, in the presence of intermittent traffic fluctuations, the system will be capable of adapting fast enough to changes in the system.
In Fig. 3, we examine the algorithm’s robustness in the presence of stochastic fluctuations and capacity constraints. First, in Fig. 3(a), we consider a network with S = 50 source nodes and D = 10 data centers with power consumption and capacity attributes as in Table I. We further assume that consumption costs are subject to stochastic disturbances

and noise with volatility coefficient σ∗ equal to a fraction z of the costs’ mean value (ranging between 0% and 100%). Remarkably, Boltzmann routing reaches a socially efficient state even under high degrees of uncertainty (up to z = 100%); however, as could be expected, the algorithm’s convergence speed decreases in the presence of large disturbances.
Finally, in Fig. 3(b), we examine the behavior of Boltzmann routing with respect to the capacity constraints imposed by the network’s links and data centers. Specifically, we run (SBR) for different routing modes (cf. Fig. 2) with a 25% disturbance level and we record the number of links and/or data centers that exceed capacity at any given time. The results are plotted in the box-and-whisker charts of Fig. 3(b) which show that routing to a single destination (over a single or several paths) consistently leads to relatively high violation percentages, between 30% and 40%. On the other hand, except for a few outliers, splitting traffic over several paths and destinations yields a much lower capacity

This behavior stems from the fact that the Pigouvian pricing scheme of Proposition 3 also penalizes users when a link (or data center) approaches capacity because the slope of the ε-adjusted cost function cεe is equal to 1/ε in that case (in our simulations, we took ε = 10−4; recall also the relevant discussion in Section II-B).
VI. Conclusions and Perspectives
The prolific increase of traffic in optical networks is forcing network operators to seek energy-efficient routing methods while facing capacity limits and random fluctuations. This paper is an attempt to propose such a scheme: specifically, we analyzed a distributed approach for energy-efficient routing in optical data networks based on the implementation of a Pigouvian pricing scheme and a learning method derived from the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. The Nash equilibria of the proposed pricing scheme coincide with the network’s socially optimum states (in terms of total energy consumption), and the resulting Boltzmann routing method converges to such states exponentially fast in realistic network conditions, leading to gains of up to 40% in energy consumption over simple, shortest-path routing schemes.
Motivated by the highly volatile nature of traffic and power consumption in optical networks, we also examine the behavior of Boltzmann routing in the presence of uncertainty and random disturbances. In this regard, we showed that the network’s long-term average consumption converges within ε of its minimum value in time which is at most Õ(ε−2), irrespective of the fluctuations’ magnitude. Moreover, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the network’s state converges to it almost surely (again, no matter the noise level); instead, if the network admits an interior, fully-mixing optimum state, the proposed scheme remains arbitrarily close to the said state with probability arbitrarily close to 1, provided that the scheme’s inverse temperature parameter η is taken sufficiently small. These theoretical results were complemented by extensive numerical simulations showing that, in realistic network conditions, Boltzmann routing provides significant advantages over closest-destination/shortest-path routing choices. In addition, the proposed method scales up to hundreds of source nodes with minimal impact on its convergence speed, and it respects the network’s capacity constraints, even under very high degrees of volatility and uncertainty.
The results presented in this paper apply to a wide range of congestion-limited network scenarios, ranging from latency minimization and throughput maximization in data networks to urban traffic management in road networks; the detailed analysis of these applications is relegated to future work. Additionally, a key question that arises is what happens in the presence of non-zero-mean fluctuations (random or not), which could lead the system’s optimum/equilibrium states to evolve over time in an arbitrary fashion (so there is no fixed underlying state to target). In this case, efficient routing protocols would have to be capable of tracking the system’s evolving optimum state in a flexible, dynamic manner; we intend to explore this issue in future work.

metadata.abstractText: Motivated by the massive deployment of power-hungry data centers for IT service provisioning, we examine the problem of routing in optical networks with the aim of minimizing traffic-driven power consumption. To tackle this issue, routing must take into account energy efficiency as well as capacity considerations; moreover, in rapidly-varying network environments, this must be accomplished in a real-time, distributed manner that remains robust in the presence of random disturbances and noise. In view of this, we derive a pricing scheme whose Nash equilibria coincide with the network’s socially optimum states, and we propose a distributed learning method based on the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. Using tools from stochastic calculus, we show that the resulting Boltzmann routing scheme exhibits remarkable convergence properties under uncertainty: specifically, the long-term average of the network’s power consumption converges within ε of its minimum value in time which is at most Õ(1/ε2), irrespective of the fluctuations’ magnitude; additionally, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the algorithm converges to it – again, no matter the noise level. Our analysis is supplemented by extensive numerical simulations which show that Boltzmann routing can lead to a significant decrease in power consumption over basic, shortest-path routing schemes in realistic network conditions. Index Terms Boltzmann routing; energy efficiency; fluctuations; optical networks; uncertainty; Nash equilibrium.
